title: Delta’s Itchy Flight Attendants Are Grounded
sub_head: A suit seeking damages for allegedly itchy uniforms fails to clear the runway
body:
Passengers on Delta Air Lines might have noticed that their flight attendants were a bit surlier than usual recently.
Possible reasons are the company’s decision to soon start charging Covid-19 vaccine holdouts an extra $200 a month for their health insurance or a surge in reports of unruly passengers. Or it could just be that they are itchy.
Delta’s new uniforms, designed by Zac Posen and manufactured by Lands’ End, were launched to great fanfare three years ago in colors including “Passport Plum.” But many employees wanted to leave the former “Project Runway” judge’s duds on the tarmac. There have been numerous complaints about skin rashes and of colors bleeding onto other garments. The airline has allowed its flight attendants to wear their own clothing along with badges indicating they are employees, and it said last year that it would redesign the uniforms.
But some current and former employees wanted more, seeking to launch a class-action suit against the manufacturer (the designer, Mr. Posen, shut down his business in 2019). The U.S. District Court for the Western District of Wisconsin last week refused to grant certification to the group. With their legal options limited, they might have to resort to disgruntled fliers’ way of attempting to right wrongs—angrily tweeting at @LandsEnd.
